st }} }} '''Xi Jinping''' ({{zh|s=习近平|p=Xí Jìnpíng}}, pronounced {{IPAc-cmn|x|i|2|-|j|in|4|.|p|ing|2}};{{efn|The closest pronunciation using only sounds common in spoken English would be ({{IPAc-en|lang|ˈ|ʃ|iː|_|tʃ|ɪ|n|ˈ|p|ɪ|ŋ}} {{respell|SHEE|_|chin|PING}}.}} born 15 June 1953) is a Chinese politician who has been the [[General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party|general secretary]] of the [[Chinese Communist Party]] (CCP) and [[Chairman of the Central Military Commission (China)|chairman]] of the [[Central Military Commission (China)|Central Military Commission]] (CMC), and thus as the [[paramount leader]] of China, since 2012. Xi has also been the [[president of the People's Republic of China]] (PRC) since 2013. He belongs to the fifth [[Generations of Chinese leadership|generation of Chinese leadership]]. {{Xi Jinping sidebar}} The son of Chinese Communist veteran [[Xi Zhongxun]], Xi was exiled to rural [[Yanchuan County]] as a teenager following his father's purge during the [[Cultural Revolution]]. He lived in a [[yaodong]] in the village of Liangjiahe, [[Shaanxi|Shaanxi province]], where he joined the CCP after several failed attempts and worked as the local [[Chinese Communist Party Committee Secretary|party secretary]]. After studying [[chemical engineering]] at [[Tsinghua University]] as a [[Worker-Peasant-Soldier student|worker-peasant-soldier student]], Xi rose through the ranks politically in China's coastal provinces. Xi was [[governor of Fujian]] from 1999 to 2002, before becoming governor and party secretary of neighboring [[Politics of Zhejiang|Zhejiang]] from 2002 to 2007. Following the dismissal of the party secretary of Shanghai, [[Chen Liangyu]], Xi was transferred to replace him for a brief period in 2007. He subsequently joined the [[Politburo Standing Committee of the Chinese Communist Party|Politburo Standing Committee]] (PSC) of the CCP the same year and was the first-ranking secretary of the [[Secretariat of the Chinese Communist Party|Central Secretariat]] in October 2007. In 2008, he was designated as [[Hu Jintao]]'s presumed [[Succession of power in China|successor]] as paramount leader; to that end, Xi was appointed [[Vice President of the People's Republic of China|vice president of the PRC]] and [[Vice Chairman of the Central Military Commission|vice chairman of the CMC]]. He officially received the title of [[leadership core]] from the CCP in 2016. Xi is the first CCP general secretary born after the [[Proclamation of the People's Republic of China|establishment of the PRC]]. Since assuming power, Xi has introduced far-ranging measures to enforce party discipline and to impose internal unity. His [[Anti-corruption campaign under Xi Jinping|anti-corruption campaign]] led to the downfall of prominent incumbent and retired CCP officials, including former PSC member [[Zhou Yongkang]]. He has also enacted or promoted a more aggressive foreign policy, particularly with regard to [[China–United States relations|China's relations with the U.S]]., the [[nine-dash line]] in the [[South China Sea Islands|South China Sea]], and the [[Sino-Indian border dispute]]. He has sought to expand China's African and Eurasian influence through the [[Belt and Road Initiative]]. Xi has expanded support for [[State-owned enterprises of China|state-owned enterprises]] (SOEs), advanced [[military-civil fusion]], overseen [[Targeted Poverty Alleviation|targeted poverty alleviation]] programs, and has attempted to reform the property sector. He has also promoted "[[common prosperity]]", a series of policies designed with stated goal to increase equality, oversaw a broad crackdown and major slew of regulations against the tech and tutoring sectors in 2021. Xi [[Ma–Xi meeting|met]] with Taiwanese president [[Ma Ying-jeou]] in 2015, the first time PRC and Republic of China leaders met, though relations deteriorated after [[Tsai Ing-wen]] of the [[Democratic Progressive Party]] (DPP) won the presidential elections in 2016. He responded to the [[COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China]] with a [[zero-COVID]] approach from January 2020 until December 2022, afterwards shifting towards a [[mitigation strategy]]. Xi also oversaw the passage of a [[Hong Kong national security law|national security law in Hong Kong]], clamping down on political opposition in the city, especially [[Pro-democracy camp (Hong Kong)|pro-democracy activists]]. Often described as an authoritarian leader by political and academic observers, Xi's tenure has included an increase of [[Censorship in China|censorship]] and [[Mass surveillance in China|mass surveillance]], deterioration in [[Human rights in China|human rights]], including the [[Xinjiang internment camps|internment of a million Uyghurs in Xinjiang]] (which some observers have described as part of [[Uyghur genocide|a genocide]]), a [[Xi Jinping's cult of personality|cult of personality]] developing around Xi, and the removal of term limits for the presidency in 2018. Xi's political ideas and principles, known as [[Xi Jinping Thought]], have been incorporated into the [[Constitution of the Chinese Communist Party|party]] and [[Constitution of the People's Republic of China|national constitutions]]. As the central figure of the [[Generations of Chinese leadership|fifth generation of leadership]] of the PRC, Xi has centralized institutional power by taking on multiple positions, including new CCP committees on national security, economic and social reforms, military restructuring and modernization, and the Internet. He and the CCP [[Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party|Central Committee]] passed a "[[Third Resolution of the CPC Central Committee on the Major Achievements and Historical Experience of the Party over the Past Century|historical resolution]]" in November 2021. In October 2022, Xi secured a third term as CCP General Secretary, and was reelected state president for a third term in March 2023. {{TOC limit|3}} ==Early life and education== Xi Jinping was born in [[Beijing]] on 15 June 1953,{{sfn|Wong|2023|p=229}} the third child of [[Xi Zhongxun]] and his second wife [[Qi Xin]]. After the [[Proclamation of the People's Republic of China|founding of the PRC]] in 1949, Xi's father held a series of posts, including [[Propaganda Department of the Chinese Communist Party|Party propaganda]] chief, [[Vice Premier of the People's Republic of China|vice-premier]], and [[Vice Chairperson of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress|vice chairperson of the National People's Congress]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/china-profile-xi-jinping/24764283.html|title=Profile: Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping|date=7 November 2012|publisher=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]|access-date=26 August 2013|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019083336/http://www.rferl.org/content/china-profile-xi-jinping/24764283.html|archive-date=19 October 2013}} Xi had two older sisters, [[Qi Qiaoqiao|Qiaoqiao]], born in 1949 and An'an ({{zh|c=安安|p=Ān'ān|labels=no}}), born in 1952.{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/book/2009-04/28/content_11270872.htm |script-title=zh:與丈夫習仲勛相伴58年 齊心：這輩子無比幸福 |date=28 April 2009 |publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |language=zh-Hant|trans-title=With her husband Xi Zhongxun for 58 years: very happy in this Xi's father was from [[Fuping County, Shaanxi|Fuping County]], Shaanxi, and Xi could further trace his [[patrilineal]] descent from Xiying in [[Dengzhou]], Henan.{{cite news |url=http://hn.wenweipo.com/news/zhuanti/2012-11-16/23713.html |script-title=zh:本報獨家探訪河南鄧州習營村|last=Fangqin|first=Sun|date=16 November 2012|work=[[Wen Wei Po]]|access-date=15 November went to the [[Beijing Bayi School]],{{cite web|last=Takahashi|first=Tetsushi|url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/Beijing-Diary/Connecting-the-dots-of-the-Hong-Kong-law-and-veneration-of-Xi|title=Connecting the dots of the Hong Kong law and veneration of Xi|newspaper=[[Nikkei Shimbun]]|date=1 June 2002|access-date=23 October 2020|archive-date=3 December 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211203074351/https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/Beijing-Diary/Connecting-the-dots-of-the-Hong-Kong-law-and-veneration-of-Xi|url-status=live}} and then the Beijing No. 25 School,{{cite web |last1=Li |first1=Cheng |title=Xi Jinping's Inner Circle (Part 2: Friends from Xi's Formative Years) |url=https://www.hoover.org/sites/default/files/research/docs/clm44cl.pdf |access-date=15 July 2020 |website=[[Hoover Institution]] |publisher= |pages=6–22 |archive-date=26 September 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200926055927/https://www.hoover.org/sites/default/files/research/docs/clm44cl.pdf |url-status=live }} in the 1960s. He became friends with [[Liu He (politician)|Liu He]], who attended [[Beijing 101 Middle School|Beijing No. 101 School]] in the same district, who later became China's vice premier and a close advisor to Xi after he became China's paramount leader.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/dec/29/power-behind-the-thrones-10-movers-and-shakers-for-2020|title=The power behind the thrones: 10 political movers and shakers who will shape 2020|last=Tisdall|first=Simon|date=29 December 2019|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=16 January 2020|language=en-GB|issn=0029-7712|author-link=Simon Tisdall|archive-date=5 November 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211105032127/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/dec/29/power-behind-the-thrones-10-movers-and-shakers-for-2020|url-status=live}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/blessed-by-xi-jinping-the-new-captain-of-chinas-economy-1519688592|title=Who Is 'Uncle He?' The Man in Charge of China's Economy|last=Wei|first=Lingling|date=27 February 2018|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|access-date=16 January 2020|archive-date=3 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211003102625/https://www.wsj.com/articles/blessed-by-xi-jinping-the-new-captain-of-chinas-economy-1519688592|url-status=live}} In 1963, when he was aged 10, his father was purged from the CCP and sent to work in a factory in [[Luoyang]], Henan.{{sfn|Bouée|2010|p=93}} In May 1966, the [[Cultural Revolution]] cut short Xi's secondary education when all secondary classes were halted for students to criticise and fight their teachers. Student militants ransacked the Xi family home and one of Xi's sisters, Xi Heping, "was persecuted to death".{{cite web |url=http://www.gapp.gov.cn/contents/2091/157500.shtml |title=习近平：“我坚信我的父亲是一个大英雄” |date=14 October 2013 |website=General Administration of Press and Publication |publisher=国家新闻出版广电总局 |access-date=6 March 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305150646/http://www.gapp.gov.cn/contents/2091/157500.shtml |archive-date=5 March 2018 |language=zh |quote=女儿习和平...在“文化大革命”中被迫害致死，是习仲勋难以抹去的心痛。 |trans-title=Xi Jinping: "I firmly believe my father is a great hero"}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/25/world/asia/xi-jinping-china-cultural-revolution.html |title=Cultural Revolution Shaped Xi Jinping, From Schoolboy to Survivor |last1=Buckley|first1=Chris |last2=Tatlow|first2=Didi Kirsten|date=24 September 2015 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=6 March 2018|url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305150638/https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/25/world/asia/xi-jinping-china-cultural-revolution.html |archive-date=5 March 2018 |url-access=limited }} Later, his mother was forced to publicly denounce his father, as he was paraded before a crowd as an enemy of the revolution. His father was later imprisoned in 1968 when Xi was aged 15. Without the protection of his father, Xi was sent to work in Liangjiahe Village, [[Wen'anyi]], [[Yanchuan County]], Yan'an, Shaanxi, in 1969 in Mao Zedong's [[Down to the Countryside Movement]].{{cite web |url=http://v.youku.com/v_show/id_XMzM2NTc1MjAwOA==.html |script-title=zh:不忘初心：是什么造就了今天的习主席？|date=30 January 2018|website=[[Youku]]|language=zh-Hans |trans-title=What Were His Original Intentions? The President Xi of Today |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180130204306/http://v.youku.com/v_show/id_XMzM2NTc1MjAwOA==.html |archive-date=30 January 2018 |access-date=30 January 2018}} He worked as the [[Chinese Communist Party Committee Secretary|party secretary]] of Liangjiahe, where he lived in a [[yaodong|cave house]].{{Cite news |last=Lim |first=Louisa |date=9 November 2012 |title=For China's Rising Leader, A Cave Was Once Home |work=[[NPR]] |publisher= |url=https://www.npr.org/2012/11/09/164684418/for-chinas-rising-leader-a-cave-was-once-home?t=1578589261050 |url-status=live |access-date=27 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180616053635/https://www.npr.org/2012/11/09/164684418/for-chinas-rising-leader-a-cave-was-once-home |archive-date=16 June 2018}} According to people who knew him, this experience led him to feel affinity with the rural poor. After a few months, unable to stand rural life, he ran away to Beijing. He was arrested during a crackdown on deserters from the countryside and sent to a work camp to dig ditches, but he later returned to the village. He then spent a total of seven years there.{{cite news|last1=Demick|first1=Barbara|last2=Pierson|first2=David|date=14 February 2012|title=China's political star Xi Jinping is a study in contrasts|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2012/02/14/chinas_political_star_xi_jinping_is_a_study_in_contrasts.html|url-status=live|access-date=24 October 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171013225355/https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2012/02/14/chinas_political_star_xi_jinping_is_a_study_in_contrasts.html|archive-date=13 October 2017}}{{cite news |author=Matt Rivers |date=19 March 2018 |title=This entire Chinese village is a shrine to Xi Jinping |work=[[CNN]] |publisher= |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/19/asia/china-xi-jinping-village-intl/index.html |access-date=11 February 2021 |archive-date=26 February 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210226054335/https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/19/asia/china-xi-jinping-village-intl/index.html |url-status=live }} The misfortunes and suffering of his family in his early years hardened Xi's view of politics. During an interview in 2000, he said, "People who have little contact with power, who are far from it, always see these things as mysterious and novel. But what I see is not just the superficial things: the power, the flowers, the glory, the applause. I see the bullpens and how people can blow hot and cold. I understand politics on a deeper level." The "bullpens" ([[:zh:牛棚 (文革用语)|牛棚]]) was a reference to [[Red Guards]]' detention houses during the Cultural Revolution.{{Cite news|last=Page|first=Jeremy|date=23 December 2020|title=How the U.S. Misread China's Xi: Hoping for a Globalist, It Got an Autocrat|language=en-US|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/xi-jinping-globalist-autocrat-misread-11608735769|access-date=25 December 2020|issn=0099-9660|archive-date=24 December 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201224233237/https://www.wsj.com/articles/xi-jinping-globalist-autocrat-misread-11608735769|url-status=live}} After seven rejections, Xi joined the [[Communist Youth League of China]] in 1971 on his eighth attempt after he befriended a local official.{{cite news |last1=Osnos |first1=Evan |author-link=Evan Osnos |date=30 March 2015 |title=Born Red |magazine=[[The New Yorker]] |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2015/04/06/born-red |url-status=live |access-date=11 September 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191004153259/https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2015/04/06/born-red |archive-date=4 October 2019}} He reunited with his father in 1972, because of a family reunion ordered by premier [[Zhou Enlai]]. From 1973, he applied to join the CCP ten times and was finally accepted on his tenth attempt in 1974.{{cite web |url=https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/china_20180318_xi_jinping_profile.pdf |title=Xi Jinping 习近平 |date= |publisher=[[Brookings Institution]] |access-date=14 October 2021 Beijing. The engineering majors there spent about 15 percent of their time studying [[Marxism–Leninism–Maoism]] and 5 percent of their time doing farm work and "learning from the People's Liberation Army".{{sfn|Simon|Cong|pp=28–29|2009}} ==Early political career== From 1979 to 1982, Xi was secretary for his father's former subordinate [[Geng Biao]], the then [[Vice Premier of the State Council of the People's Republic of China|vice premier]] and secretary-general of the CMC. In 1982, he was sent to [[Zhengding County]] in Hebei as deputy party secretary of Zhengding County. He was promoted in 1983 to secretary, becoming the top official of the county.{{Cite news |last=Johnson |first=Ian |date=2012-09-30 |title=Elite and Deft, Xi Aimed High Early in China |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/30/world/asia/aiming-for-top-xi-jinping-forged-ties-early-in-china.html |access-date=2023-04-04 |issn=0362-4331 |archive-date=30 September 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930091232/http://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/30/world/asia/aiming-for-top-xi-jinping-forged-ties-early-in-china.html |url-status=live }} Xi subsequently served in four provinces during his regional political career: Hebei (1982–1985), [[Fujian]] (1985–2002), [[Zhejiang]] (2002–2007), and Shanghai (2007).{{cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/xi-jinping-from-graft-fighting-governor-to-chinas-most-powerful-leader-since-mao|title=Xi Jinping: From graft-fighting governor to China's most powerful leader since Mao Zedong|date=11 March 2018|newspaper=[[The Straits Times]]|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190818052957/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/xi-jinping-from-graft-fighting-governor-to-chinas-most-powerful-leader-since-mao|archive-date=18 August 2019|access-date=18 August 2019}} Xi held posts in the [[Fuzhou]] Municipal Party Committee and became the president of the Party School in Fuzhou in 1990. In 1997, he was named an alternate member of the [[15th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party|15th Central Committee of the CCP]]. However, of the 151 alternate members of the Central Committee elected at the 15th Party Congress, Xi received the lowest number of votes in favour, placing him last in the rankings of members, ostensibly due to his status as a [[Princelings|princeling]].{{efn|[[Liu Yandong]], [[Wang Qishan]], and [[Deng Pufang]] (Deng Xiaoping's son) all placed among the bottom of the alternate member list. Like Xi, all three were seen as "princelings". [[Bo Xilai]] was not elected to the Central Committee at all; that is, Bo placed lower in the vote count than Xi.}}{{cite news |url=http://www.canyu.org/n24349c6.aspx |script-title=zh:中共十五大习近平位列候补委员最后一名为何 |date=22 April 2011|website=Canyu.org|access-date=7 September 2019|language=zh-Hans|trans-title=Why Is Xi Jinping, At the 15th CCP National Congress, Being Waited On To Fill The Last Committee Member Position?|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612141334/http://www.canyu.org/n24349c6.aspx|archive-date=12 June 2018|url-status=usurped|title=中共十五大习近平位列候补委员最后一名为何}} From 1998 to 2002, Xi studied [[Marxism|Marxist]] theory and ideological education in Tsinghua University,{{cite web|url=http://en.people.cn/90001/90776/6288506.html|title=Xi Jinping – Politburo Standing Committee member of CPC Central Committee |date=22 October 2007|website=[[People's Daily]]|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150630190420/http://en.people.cn/90001/90776/6288506.html|archive-date=30 June 2015|access-date=30 October 2019}} graduating with a doctorate in law and ideology in 2002.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/oct/26/china.uknews4|title=Most corrupt officials are from poor families but Chinese royals have a spirit that is not dominated by money|last=Watts|first=Jonathan|date=26 October 2007|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=11 June 2008|location=London, England|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130901014357/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/oct/26/china.uknews4|archive-date=1 September 2013|url-status=live}} In 1999, he was promoted to the office of Vice Governor of Fujian, and became governor a year later. In Fujian, Xi made efforts to attract investment from Taiwan and to strengthen the private sector of the provincial economy.{{cite news|url=https://thediplomat.com/2014/11/from-fujian-chinas-xi-offers-economic-olive-branch-to-taiwan/|title=From Fujian, China's Xi Offers Economic Olive Branch to Taiwan|last=Tiezzi|first=Shannon|date=4 November 2014|newspaper=[[The Diplomat]]|language=en-US|url-access=limited|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610145941/https://thediplomat.com/2014/11/from-fujian-chinas-xi-offers-economic-olive-branch-to-taiwan/|archive-date=10 June 2016|access-date=17 March 2016}} In February 2000, he and then-provincial party secretary [[Chen Mingyi]] were called before the top members of PSC – general secretary [[Jiang Zemin]], premier [[Zhu Rongji]], vice president [[Hu Jintao]] and [[Central Commission for Discipline Inspection|Discipline Inspection]] secretary [[Wei Jianxing]] – to explain aspects of the [[Yuanhua scandal]].{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/article/308424/fujian-leaders-face-beijing-top-brass|title=Fujian leaders face Beijing top brass|last=Yu|first=Xiao|date=18 February 2000|newspaper=[[South China Morning Post]]|access-date=7 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181029030831/https://www.scmp.com/article/308424/fujian-leaders-face-beijing-top-brass|archive-date=29 October 2018|url-status=live}} In 2002, Xi left Fujian and took up leading political positions in neighbouring Zhejiang. He eventually took over as provincial Party Committee secretary after several months as acting governor, occupying a top provincial office for the first time in his career. In 2002, he was elected a full member of the [[16th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party|16th Central Committee]], marking his ascension to the national stage. While in Zhejiang, Xi presided over reported growth rates averaging 14% per year.{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1068825/chinas-leadership-transition-xi-jinpings-time-zhejiang|title=Xi Jinping's time in Zhejiang: doing the business|last=Ho|first=Louise|date=25 October 2012|newspaper=[[South China Morning Post]]|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160429160349/http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1068825/chinas-leadership-transition-xi-jinpings-time-zhejiang|archive-date=29 April 2016|access-date=9 December 2019}} His career in Zhejiang was marked by a tough and straightforward stance against corrupt officials. This earned him a name in the national media and drew the attention of China's top leaders.{{cite news|url=http://opinion.dwnews.com/news/2014-12-25/59626005.html |script-title=zh:习近平为官之道 拎着乌纱帽干事|last1=Wang|first1=Lei|date=25 December 2014|work=[[Duowei News]]|access-date=7 September 2019|language=zh-hans|trans-title=Xi Jinping's Governmental Path – Carries Official Administrative Posts|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150203225014/http://opinion.dwnews.com/news/2014-12-25/59626005.html|archive-date=3 February 2015}} Between 2004 and 2007, [[Li Qiang]] acted as Xi's chief of staff through his position as secretary-general of the Zhejiang Party Committee, where they developed close mutual ties.{{Cite news |last1=Tian |first1=Yew Lun |last2=Chen |first2=Laurie |last3=Cash |first3=Joe |date=11 March 2023 |title=Li Qiang, Xi confidant, takes reins as China's premier |work=[[Reuters]] Shanghai [[Chinese Communist Party Shanghai Committee|Party secretary]] [[Chen Liangyu]] in September 2006 due to a [[Shanghai pension scandal|social security fund scandal]], Xi was transferred to Shanghai in March 2007, where he was the party secretary there for seven months.{{cite news|url=http://news.sohu.com/20070324/n248946143.shtml|script-title=zh:习近平任上海市委书记 韩正不再代理市委书记|date=24 March August 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190909102154/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20322288 |archive-date=9 September 2019}} In Shanghai, Xi avoided controversy and was known for strictly observing party discipline. For example, Shanghai administrators attempted to earn favour with him by arranging a special train to shuttle him between Shanghai and [[Hangzhou]] for him to complete handing off his work to his successor as Zhejiang party secretary [[Zhao Hongzhu]]. However, Xi reportedly refused to take the train, citing a loosely enforced party regulation that stipulated that special trains can only be reserved for "national leaders".{{cite news|url=http://www.boxun.com/news/gb/china/2013/07/201307110449.shtml#.VTxXVvnF_tU|script-title=zh:从上海到北京 习近平贴身秘书只有钟绍军|date=11 July 2013|work=[[Mingjing News]]|access-date=12 September 2019|language=zh-hans|trans-title=From Shanghai to Beijing, Zhong Shaojun Has Been Xi Jinping's Only Personal Secretary|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612141343/http://www.boxun.com/news/gb/china/2013/07/201307110449.shtml#.VTxXVvnF_tU|archive-date=12 June 2018|url-status=live}} While in Shanghai, he worked on preserving unity of the local party organisation. He pledged there would be no 'purges' during his administration, despite the fact many local officials were thought to have been implicated in the Chen Liangyu corruption scandal.{{sfn|Lam|2015|p=56}} On most issues, Xi largely echoed the line of the central leadership.{{cite news|url=http://www.caijing.com.cn/2007-10-22/100034588.html |script-title=zh:新晋政治局常委：习近平|date=22 October 2007|work=[[Caijing]]|access-date=12 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222175301/http://www.caijing.com.cn/2007-10-22/100034588.html|archive-date=22 December 2015|language=zh-hans|trans-title=Newly Appointed Member of Politburo Standing Committee: Xi Jinping}} ==Rise to power== [[File:President George W. Bush with Vice President Xi Jinping.jpg|thumb|Xi Jinping greeting U.S. president [[George W. Bush]] in August 2008|left]] [[File:Dmitry Medvedev in China 28 September 2010-6.jpeg|thumb|Xi Jinping with Russian president [[Dmitry Medvedev]] on 28 September 2010|left]] Xi was appointed to the nine-man PSC at the [[17th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party|17th Party Congress]] in October 2007. He was ranked above [[Li Keqiang]], an indication that he was going to succeed Hu Jintao as China's [[Succession of power in China|next leader]]. In addition, Xi also held the [[First Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party|first secretary]] of the CCP's [[Secretariat of the Chinese Communist Party|Central Secretariat]]. This assessment was further supported at the [[11th National People's Congress]] in March 2008, when Xi was elected as vice president of the PRC.{{Cite web |date=16 March 2008 |title=Wen Jiabao re-elected China PM |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2008/3/16/wen-jiabao-re-elected-china-pm |access-date=13 August 2022 |website=[[Al Jazeera English|Al Jazeera]] |language=en |archive-date=13 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220813171805/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2008/3/16/wen-jiabao-re-elected-china-pm |url-status=live }} Following his elevation, Xi held a broad range of portfolios. He was put in charge of the comprehensive preparations for the [[2008 Summer Olympics]] in Beijing, as well as being the central government's leading figure in Hong Kong and Macau affairs. In addition, he also became the new president of the [[Central Party School of the Chinese Communist Party|Central Party School]] of the CCP, its cadre-training and ideological education wing. In the wake of the [[2008 Sichuan earthquake]], Xi visited disaster areas in [[Shaanxi]] and [[Gansu]]. He made his first foreign trip as vice president to North Korea, Mongolia, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Yemen from 17 to 25 June 2008.{{cite web |date=5 June 2008 |title=Vice-President Xi Jinping to Visit DPRK, Mongolia, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Yemen |url=http://www.mfa.gov.cn/eng/wjdt/wsrc/t462294.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723214209/http://www.mfa.gov.cn/eng/wjdt/wsrc/t462294.htm |archive-date=23 July 2011 |access-date=20 October 2010 |website=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] |publisher=}} After the Olympics, Xi was assigned the post of committee chair for the preparations of the [[60th Anniversary of the People's Republic of China|60th Anniversary Celebrations]] of the founding of the PRC. He was also reportedly at the helm of a top-level CCP committee dubbed the [[6521 Project]], which was charged with ensuring social stability during a series of politically sensitive anniversaries in 2009.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/10/world/asia/10china.html|title=China's Leaders See a Calendar Full of Anniversaries, and Trouble|last=Wines|first=Michael|date=9 March 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=8 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160721045913/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/10/world/asia/10china.html|archive-date=21 July 2016|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|url-access=limited}} Xi's position as the apparent successor to become the paramount leader was threatened with the rapid rise of [[Bo Xilai]], the party secretary of [[Chongqing]] at the time. Bo was expected to join the PSC at the [[18th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party|18th Party Congress]], with most expecting that he would try to eventually maneuver himself into replacing Xi.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/d67b90f0-d140-11e1-8957-00144feabdc0|archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20221211221204/https://www.ft.com/content/d67b90f0-d140-11e1-8957-00144feabdc0|archive-date=11 December 2022|url-access=subscription|url-status=live|title=Bo Xilai: power, death and politics|last=Anderlini|first=Jamil|date=20 July 2012|work=[[Financial Times]]|access-date=11 January 2020}} Bo's policies in Chongqing inspired imitations throughout China and received praise from Xi himself during Xi's visit to Chongqing in 2010. Records of praises from Xi were later erased after he became paramount leader. Bo's downfall would come with the [[Wang Lijun incident]], which opened the door for Xi to come to power without challengers.{{Cite news|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/10/19/the-resistible-rise-of-xi-jinping/|title=The Resistible Rise of Xi Jinping|last=Palmer|first=James|date=19 October 2017|work=[[Foreign Policy (magazine)|Foreign Policy]]|access-date=11 January 2020|archive-date=6 February 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200206195505/https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/10/19/the-resistible-rise-of-xi-jinping/|url-status=live}} Xi is considered one of the most successful members of the Princelings, a quasi-clique of politicians who are descendants of early Chinese Communist revolutionaries. Former prime minister of Singapore, [[Lee Kuan Yew]], when asked about Xi, said he felt he was "a thoughtful man who has gone through many trials and tribulations".{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsweek.com/xi-jinping-chinas-new-boss-and-l-word-95021|title=Xi Jinping: China's New Boss And The 'L' Word|last=Ansfield|first=Jonathan|date=22 December 2007|work=[[Newsweek]]|access-date=20 October 2010|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330064319/http://www.newsweek.com/id/81558|archive-date=30 March 2010}} Lee also commented: "I would put him in the [[Nelson Mandela]] class of persons. A person with enormous emotional stability who does not allow his personal misfortunes or sufferings affect his judgment. In other words, he is impressive".{{cite news|url=http://china.blogs.time.com/2007/11/19/chinas_nelson_mandela/|title=China's Nelson Mandela|last=Elegant|first=Simon|date=19 November 2007|magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|access-date=8 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090728171010/http://china.blogs.time.com/2007/11/19/chinas_nelson_mandela/|archive-date=28 The home was turned into a museum decades later.]] In the [[European Union]], Xi visited Belgium, Germany, Bulgaria, Hungary and Romania from 7 to 21 October 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.china-un.ch/eng/xwdt/t622138.htm|title=A Journey of Friendship, Cooperation and Culture – Vice Foreign Minister Zhang Zhijun Sums Up Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping's Trip to 5 European Countries|date=21 October 2009|publisher=[[Permanent Representative of China to the United Nations]]|access-date=11 September 2019|archive-date=3 February 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200203050934/http://www.china-un.ch/eng/xwdt/t622138.htm|url-status=live}} He visited Japan, South Korea, Cambodia, and Myanmar on his Asian trip from 14 to 22 December 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.southasiaanalysis.org/papers36/paper3566.html|title=China's Cousin-Cousin Relations with Myanmar|last=Raman|first=B.|date=25 December 2009|publisher=[[South Asia Analysis Group]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100317074826/http://www.southasiaanalysis.org/papers36/paper3566.html|archive-date=17 March 2010|access-date=14 February 2012}} He later visited the United States, Ireland and Turkey in February 2012. He then reappeared on 15 September.{{Cite magazine |last=Beech |first=Hannah |date=15 September 2012 |title=China's Heir Apparent Xi Jinping Reappears in Public After a Two-Week Absence |url=https://world.time.com/2012/09/15/chinas-heir-apparent-xi-jinping-reappears-in-public-after-a-two-week-absence/ |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |language=en-US |issn=0040-781X |access-date=20 August 2022 |archive-date=14 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220814104509/https://world.time.com/2012/09/15/chinas-heir-apparent-xi-jinping-reappears-in-public-after-a-two-week-absence/ |url-status=live }} On 15 November 2012, Xi was elected to the posts of general secretary of the CCP and chairman of the CMC by the [[18th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party|18th Central Committee of the CCP]]. This made him, informally, the [[paramount leader]] and the first to be born after the founding of the PRC. The following day Xi led the new line-up of the PSC onto the stage in their first public appearance.{{cite news |date=17 November 2012 |title=China Confirms Leadership Change |work=[[BBC News]] July 2014}} Xi mentioned the aspirations of the average person, remarking, "Our people ... expect better education, more stable jobs, better income, more reliable social security, medical care of a higher standard, more comfortable living conditions, and a more beautiful environment." Xi also vowed to tackle corruption at the highest levels, alluding that it would threaten the CCP's survival; he was reticent about far-reaching economic reforms.{{cite news |date=15 November 2012 |title=Full text: China's new party chief Xi Jinping's speech |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher= |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20338586 |url-status=live |access-date=7 September 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190914232334/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20338586 |archive-date=14 September 2019}} In December 2012, Xi visited [[Guangdong]] in his first trip outside Beijing since taking the Party leadership. The overarching theme of the trip was to call for further economic reform and a strengthened military. Xi visited the statue of Deng Xiaoping and his trip was described as following in the footsteps of [[Deng Xiaoping#Resignation and 1992 southern tour|Deng's own southern trip in 1992]], which provided the impetus for further economic reforms in China after conservative party leaders stalled many of Deng's reforms in the aftermath of the [[1989 Tiananmen Square protests and massacre]]. On his trip, Xi consistently alluded to his signature slogan, the "Chinese Dream". "This dream can be said to be the dream of a strong nation. And for the military, it is a dream of a strong military", Xi told sailors.{{cite news |last=Page |first=Jeremy |date=13 March 2013 |title=New Beijing Leader's 'China Dream' |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324128504578348774040546346 |url-status=live |access-date=8 September 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191011195356/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324128504578348774040546346 |archive-date=11 October 2019}} Xi's trip was significant in that he departed from the established convention of Chinese leaders' travel routines in multiple ways. Rather than dining out, Xi and his entourage ate regular hotel buffet. He travelled in a large van with his colleagues rather than a fleet of limousines, and did not restrict traffic on the parts of the highway he travelled.{{cite news |last1=Chen |first1=Zhuang |date=10 December 2012 |title=The symbolism of Xi Jinping's trip south |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher= |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20662947 |url-status=live |access-date=22 July 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140708094339/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20662947 |archive-date=8 July 2014}} Xi was elected president on 14 March 2013, in a confirmation vote by the [[12th National People's Congress]] in Beijing. He received 2,952 for, one vote against, and three abstentions. He replaced Hu Jintao, who retired after serving two terms.{{cite news |last=Demick |first=Barbara |author-link=Barbara Demick |date=3 March 2013 |title=China's Xi Jinping formally assumes title of 2013}} Within hours of his election, Xi discussed [[cyber security]] and North Korea with U.S. President Barack Obama over the phone. Obama announced the visits of treasury and state secretaries [[Jacob Lew]] and [[John F. Kerry]] to China the following week.{{cite news |date=15 March 2013 |title=China names Xi Jinping as new president |website=Inquirer.net |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/373967/china-names-xi-jinping-as-new-president |url-status=live |access-date=16 March 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130317020402/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/373967/china-names-xi-jinping-as-new-president |archive-date=17 March 2013}} ==Leadership== {{Main|Xi Jinping Administration}} ===Anti-corruption campaign=== {{main|Anti-corruption campaign under Xi Jinping}} {{Quote box | quote = “To speak the truth” means to focus on the nature of things, to speak frankly, and follow the truth. This is an important embodiment of a leading official’s characteristics of truth seeking, embodying justice, devotion to public interests, and uprightness. Moreover, he highlighted that the premise of telling the truth is to listen to the truth. | source = — Xi Jinping during a speech in 2012{{cite book | last=People’s Daily | first=Department of Commentary | title=Narrating China's Governance | chapter=Stories of Incorrupt Government: “The Corruption and Unjustness of Officials Give Birth to the Decline of Governance” | publisher=Springer Singapore | publication-place=Singapore | date=20 Nov 2019 | isbn=978-981-329-177-5 | doi=10.1007/978-981-32-9178-2_1 | pages=3–39}}{{cite web | title=習近平:不提不切實際的口號 - 快訊-文匯網 | website=香港文匯網 | date=29 May 2012 | url=http://news.wenweipo.com/2012/05/29/IN1205290017.htm | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230928143655/http://news.wenweipo.com/2012/05/29/IN1205290017.htm | archive-date=28 Sep 2023 | url-status=live | access-date=28 Sep 2023}} | align = right | width = 25em }} Xi vowed to crack down on corruption almost immediately after he ascended to power at the 18th Party Congress. In his inaugural speech as general secretary, Xi mentioned that fighting corruption was one of the toughest challenges for the party.{{cite news |date=15 November 2012 |title=Xi Jinping's inaugural Speech |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher= |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20338586 |url-status=live |access-date=7 September 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190914232334/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-20338586 |archive-date=14 September 2019}} A few months into his term, Xi outlined the [[Eight-point Regulation]], listing rules intended to curb corruption and waste during official party business; it aimed at stricter discipline on the conduct of party officials. Xi also vowed to root out "tigers and flies", that is, high-ranking officials and ordinary party functionaries.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/28/world/asia/xi-jinping-imposes-austerity-measures-on-chinas-elite.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|title=Elite in China Face Austerity Under Xi's Rule|last=Jacobs|first=Andrew|date=27 March 2013|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=7 September 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181130054920/https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/28/world/asia/xi-jinping-imposes-austerity-measures-on-chinas-elite.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|archive-date=30 November 2018|author-link=Andrew Jacobs (journalist)}} Xi initiated cases against former CMC vice-chairmen [[Xu Caihou]] and [[Guo Boxiong]], former PSC member and security chief [[Zhou Yongkang]] and former Hu Jintao chief aide [[Ling Jihua]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-03-03/china-s-xi-broadens-graft-crackdown-to-boost-influence.html|title=President Xi's Anti-Corruption Campaign Biggest Since Mao|last=Oster|first=Shai|date=4 March 2014|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]|access-date=7 September 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209164917/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-03-03/china-s-xi-broadens-graft-crackdown-to-boost-influence.html|archive-date=9 December 2014|author-link=Shai Oster}} Along with new disciplinary chief [[Wang Qishan]], Xi's [[Xi–Li Administration|administration]] spearheaded the formation of "centrally-dispatched inspection teams" ({{lang|zh-hans|中央巡视组}}). These were essentially cross-jurisdictional squads of officials whose main task was to gain more in-depth understanding of the operations of provincial and local party organizations, and in the process, also enforce party discipline mandated by Beijing. Many of the work teams also had the effect of identifying and initiating investigations of high-ranking officials. Over one hundred provincial-ministerial level officials were implicated during a massive nationwide anti-corruption campaign. These included former and current regional officials ([[Su Rong]], [[Bai Enpei]], [[Wan Qingliang]]), leading figures of state-owned enterprises and central government organs ([[Song Lin]], [[Liu Tienan]]), and highly ranked generals in the military ([[Gu Junshan]]). In June 2014, the [[Shanxi]] provincial political establishment was decimated, with four officials dismissed within a week from the provincial party organization's top ranks. Within the first two years of the campaign alone, over 200,000 low-ranking officials received warnings, fines, and demotions.{{sfn|Heilmann|2017|pp=62–75}} The campaign has led to the downfall of prominent incumbent and retired CCP officials, including members of the PSC.{{cite news|url=http://www.jamestown.org/programs/chinabrief/single/?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=43160&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=25&cHash=d5d24d2f82c5981963c0180d300e62cd#.VOOBN_nF9uM|title=China's Soft-Power Commission for Discipline Inspection (CCDI), CCP's highest [[internal control]] institution.{{cite news |date=13 June 2014 |title=31个省级纪委改革方案获批复 12省已完成纪委"重建" |trans-title=31 Provincial Commission for CCDI Secretary Wang Qishan further institutionalized CCDI's independence from the day-to-day operations of the CCP, improving its ability to function as a ''bona fide'' control body. According to ''The Wall Street Journal'', any anti-corruption punishment to officials at or above the vice ministerial level need approval from Xi.{{Cite news |last=Chin |first=Josh |date=15 December 2021 |title=Xi Jinping's Leadership Style: Micromanagement That Leaves Underlings Scrambling |language=en-US |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/xi-jinpings-leadership-style-micromanagement-that-leaves-underlings-scrambling-11639582426 |access-date=13 August 2022 |issn=0099-9660 |archive-date=13 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220813143342/https://www.wsj.com/articles/xi-jinpings-leadership-style-micromanagement-that-leaves-underlings-scrambling-11639582426 |url-status=live }} Another article from ''The Wall Street Journal'' said that when he wants to neutralize a political rival, he asks inspectors to prepare hundreds of pages of evidence. The article also said that he sometimes authorizes investigations on close associates of a high-ranking politician to replace them with his own proteges and puts political rivals in less important positions to separate them from their political bases. Reportedly, these tactics have even been used against Wang Qishan, Xi's close friend.{{Cite news |last=Wong |first=Chun Han |date=16 October 2022 |title=Xi Jinping's Quest for Control Over China Targets Even Old Friends |language=en-US |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/xi-jinping-china-anticorruption-11665925166 |access-date=17 October 2022 |issn=0099-9660 |archive-date=16 October 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221016230010/https://www.wsj.com/articles/xi-jinping-china-anticorruption-11665925166 |url-status=live }} According to [[historian]] and [[sinologist]] [[Wang Gungwu]], Xi Jinping inherited a political party that was faced with pervasive corruption.{{Cite web |date=19 March 2021 |title=China re-connects: joining a deep-rooted past to a new world order |url=https://www.jesus.cam.ac.uk/articles/china-re-connects-joining-deep-rooted-past-new-world-order |access-date=2023-02-11 |website=[[Jesus College, Cambridge]] |language=en |archive-date=11 February 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230211132318/https://www.jesus.cam.ac.uk/articles/china-re-connects-joining-deep-rooted-past-new-world-order |url-status=live }}{{Cite news |last=Wang |first=Gungwu |author-link=Wang Gungwu |date=7 September 2019 |title=Ancient past, modern ambitions: historian Wang Gungwu's new book on China's delicate balance |work=[[South China Morning Post]] |url=https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3026041/ancient-past-modern-ambitions-historian-wang-gungwus-new-book |access-date=11 February 2023 |archive-date=11 February 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230211175223/https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3026041/ancient-past-modern-ambitions-historian-wang-gungwus-new-book |url-status=live }} Xi believed that the amount of corruption at the higher levels of the CCP put both the party and the country at risk of collapse. Wang further adds that Xi has a belief that only the CCP is capable of governing China, and that a collapse of the party would be disastrous for the Chinese people. ===Reforms=== In November 2013, at the conclusion of the Third Plenum of the 18th Central Committee, the Communist Party delivered a far-reaching reform agenda that alluded to changes in both economic and social policy. Xi signaled at the plenum that he was consolidating control of the massive internal security organization that was formerly the domain of [[Zhou Yongkang]].{{cite news |last1=Kroeber |first1=Arthur R. |date=17 November 2013 |title=Xi Jinping's Ambitious Agenda for Economic Reform in China |work=[[Brookings Institution]] |publisher= |url=http://www.brookings.edu/research/opinions/2013/11/17-xi-jinping-economic-agenda-kroeber |url-status=live |access-date=21 July 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140727211348/http://www.brookings.edu/research/opinions/2013/11/17-xi-jinping-economic-agenda-kroeber |archive-date=27 July 2014}} A new National Security Commission was formed with Xi at its helm. The [[Central Leading Group for Comprehensively Deepening Reforms]]—another ''ad hoc'' policy coordination body led by Xi upgraded to a commission in 2018—was also formed to oversee the implementation of the reform agenda.{{Cite web |last=Jun |first=Mai |date=21 March 2018 |title=China unveils bold overhaul to tighten Communist Party control |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/china/policies-politics/article/2138291/china-unveils-bold-overhaul-tighten-communist-party |access-date=13 August 2022 |website=[[South China Morning Post]] |language=en |archive-date=13 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220813171805/https://www.scmp.com/news/china/policies-politics/article/2138291/china-unveils-bold-overhaul-tighten-communist-party |url-status=live }} Termed "comprehensive deepening reforms" ({{zh|labels=no|s=全面深化改革|p=quánmiàn shēnhuà gǎigé}}), they were said to be the most significant since Deng Xiaoping's 1992 Southern Tour. The plenum also announced economic reforms and resolved to abolish the ''[[laogai]]'' system of "[[Re-education through labor|re-education through labour]]", which was largely seen as a blot on China's human rights record. The system has faced significant criticism for years from domestic critics and foreign observers. In January 2016, a [[two-child policy]] replaced the [[one-child policy]],{{cite news|last=Sridahan|first=Vasudevan|date=27 December 2015|title=China formally abolishes decades-old one-child policy|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/china-formally-abolishes-decades-old-one-child-policy-1535006|url-status=live|access-date=7 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190828224908/https://www.ibtimes.co.uk/china-formally-abolishes-decades-old-one-child-policy-1535006|archive-date=28 August 2019}} which was in turn was replaced with a [[three-child policy]] in May 2021.{{Cite news |last=Wee |first=Sui-Lee |date=31 May 2021 |title=China Says It Will Allow Couples to Have 3 Children, Up From 2 |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/31/world/asia/china-three-child-policy.html |access-date=11 August 2022 |issn=0362-4331 |archive-date=4 November 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211104064050/https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/31/world/asia/china-three-child-policy.html |url-status=live }} In July 2021, all family size limits as well as penalties for exceeding them were removed.{{Cite web |last=Cheng |first=Evelyn |date=21 July 2021 |title=China scraps fines, will let families have as many children as they'd like |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/21/china-scraps-fines-for-families-violating-childbirth-limits.html |access-date=29 April 2022 |website=[[CNBC]] |language=en |archive-date=28 January 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230128131149/https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/21/china-scraps-fines-for-families-violating-childbirth-limits.html |url-status=live }} ==== Political reforms ==== Xi's administration taken a number of changes to the structure of the CCP and state bodies, [[2018 party and government reform in China|especially in a large overhaul in 2018]]. In March 2014, the CCP Central Committee merged the Office for External Propaganda (OEP), externally known as the [[State Council Information Office]] (SCIO), to the CCP's [[Central Propaganda Department of the Chinese Communist Party|Central Propaganda Department]]. SCIO is now used by the Central Propaganda Department as an external name under an arrangement called "[[one institution with two names]]".{{Cite web |last1=Lulu |first1=Jichang |last2=Jirouš |first2=Filip |last3=Lee |first3=Rachel |date=2021-01-25 |title=Xi's centralisation of external propaganda: SCIO and the Central Propaganda Department |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220203220603/https://sinopsis.cz/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/scio.pdf |archive-date=3 Feb 2022 |url=https://sinopsis.cz/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/scio.pdf |url-status=live |access-date=2021-11-20 |website=Sinopsis |language=en-US}} February earlier that year oversaw the creation of the [[Central Cyberspace Affairs Commission|Central Leading Group for Cybersecurity and Informatization]]. The State Internet Information Office (SIIO), previously under the OEP and SCIO, was transferred to the central leading group and renamed in English into the [[Cyberspace Administration of China]].{{Cite web |last1=Attrill |first1=Nathan |last2=Fritz |first2=Audrey |date=24 November 2021 |title=China's cyber vision: How the Cyberspace Administration of China is building a new consensus on global internet governance |url=https://ad-aspi.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/2021-11/Chinas%20cyber%20vision.pdf?VersionId=M0ePH4Ij3w7WRJrLlhyxVvt269MWSYOs |access-date=29 December 2022 |website=[[Australian Strategic Policy Institute]] |archive-date=29 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221229145556/https://ad-aspi.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/2021-11/Chinas%20cyber%20vision.pdf?VersionId=M0ePH4Ij3w7WRJrLlhyxVvt269MWSYOs |url-status=live }} As part of managing the financial system, the [[Financial Stability and Development Committee]], a State Council body, was established in 2017. Chaired by vice premier [[Liu He (politician)|Liu He]] during its existence, the committee was disestablished by the newly established Central Financial Commission during the 2023 Party and state reforms.{{Cite news |last1=Chen |first1=Laurie |last2=Tang |first2=Ziyi |date=16 March 2023 |title=China to create powerful financial watchdog run by Communist Party |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/china/china-create-powerful-financial-watchdog-run-by-communist-party-2023-03-16/ |access-date=17 March 2023 |archive-date=16 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230316162813/https://www.reuters.com/world/china/china-create-powerful-financial-watchdog-run-by-communist-party-2023-03-16/ |url-status=live }} 2018 has seen larger reforms to the bureaucracy. In that year, several [[Leading Small Group|central leading groups]] including [[Central Comprehensively Deepening Reforms Commission|reform]], cyberspace affairs, [[Central Financial and Economic Affairs Commission|finance and economics]]. and [[Central Foreign Affairs Commission|foreign affairs]] were upgraded to commissions.{{Cite news |date=22 March 2018 |title=CPC releases plan on deepening reform of Party and state institutions |work=[[People's Daily]] |url=http://en.people.cn/n3/2018/0322/c90000-9440252.html |access-date=29 December 2022 |archive-date=5 February 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210205013244/http://en.people.cn/n3/2018/0322/c90000-9440252.html |url-status=live }}{{Cite news |last=Buckley |first=Chris |date=2018-03-21 |title=China Gives Communist Party More Control Over Policy and Media |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/21/world/asia/china-communist-party-xi-jinping.html |access-date=2022-12-29 |issn=0362-4331 |archive-date=12 November 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211112211222/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/21/world/asia/china-communist-party-xi-jinping.html |url-status=live }} In the area of media, the State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television (SAPPRFT) was renamed into the [[National Radio and Television Administration]] (NRTA) with its film, news media and publications being transferred to the Central Propaganda Department. Additionally, the control of China Central Television (CCTV, including its international edition, [[China Global Television Network|China Global Television]]), [[China National Radio]] (CNR) and [[China Radio International]] (CRI) were transferred to the newly established [[China Media Group]] (CMG) under the control of the Central Propaganda Department.{{Cite news |date=22 March 2018 |title=三台合一，发出更强"中国之声" |trans-title=Merge of Three Stations into One, Sending Out a Stronger "Voice of China" |work=[[People's Daily]] |url=http://politics.people.com.cn/GB/n1/2018/0322/c1001-29883390.html |access-date=29 December 2022 |archive-date=10 September 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210910022043/http://politics.people.com.cn/GB/n1/2018/0322/c1001-29883390.html |url-status=live }} Two State Council departments. one dealing with [[Overseas Chinese Affairs Office|overseas Chinese]], and other one dealing with [[State Administration for Religious Affairs|religious affairs]], were merged into the [[United Front Work Department]] while another commission dealing with [[National Ethnic Affairs Commission|ethnic affairs]] was brought under formal UFWD leadership. 2023 has seen further reforms to the CCP and state bureaucracy, most notably the strengthening of Party control over the financial and technology domains.{{Cite news |last1=Wong |first1=Chun Han |last2=Zhai |first2=Keith |date=16 March 2023 |title=China's Communist Party Overhaul Deepens Control Over Finance, Technology |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/chinas-communist-party-overhaul-deepens-control-over-finance-technology-6acdd43c?mod=world_lead_pos5 |access-date=16 March 2023 |archive-date=16 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230316221649/https://www.wsj.com/articles/chinas-communist-party-overhaul-deepens-control-over-finance-technology-6acdd43c?mod=world_lead_pos5 |url-status=live }} This included the creation of two CCP bodies for overseeing finance; the [[Central Financial Commission]] (CFC), as well as the revival of the [[Central Financial Work Commission]] (CFWC) that was previously dissolved in 2002. The CFC would broadly manage the financial system while the CFWC would focus on strengthening the ideological and political role of the CCP in the sector. Additionally, a new CCP [[Central Science and Technology Commission]] would be established to broadly oversee the technology sector, while a newly created [[Social Work Department]] was tasked with CCP interactions with several sectors, including civic groups, chambers of commerce and industry groups, as well as handling public petition and grievance work. A new Central Hong Kong and Macau Work Office would also be established, with the State Council's Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office being turned into the new body's external name. At the State Council, the [[China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission]] was replaced by the [[National Administration of Financial Regulation]] (NAFR), which is taking a much larger responsibility on financial regulation, effectively overseeing all financial activities except the securities industry, which was continued to be regulated by the [[China Securities Regulatory Commission]], now elevated to a government body.{{Cite news |date=7 March 2023 |title=China Overhauls Financial Regulatory Regime to Control Risks |work=[[Bloomberg News]] title=习近平出席中央全面依法治国工作会议并发表重要讲话 | website=Chinadaily.com.cn | date=18 Nov 2020 | url=https://language.chinadaily.com.cn/a/202011/18/WS5fb4ad35a31024ad0ba94eb8.html | 2023}} | align = right | width = 25em }} The party under Xi announced a raft of [[Law reform|legal reforms]] at the Fourth Plenum held in the fall 2014, and he called for "[[Rule of law in China|Chinese socialistic rule of law]]" immediately afterwards. The party aimed to reform the legal system, which had been perceived as ineffective at delivering justice and affected by corruption, local government interference and lack of constitutional oversight. The plenum, while emphasizing the absolute leadership of the party, also called for a greater role of the constitution in the affairs of state and a strengthening of the role of the National People's Congress Standing Committee in interpreting the constitution.{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1623286/communist-party-pledges-greater-role-constitution-rights-fourth-plenum|title=Communist Party pledges greater role for constitution, rights in fourth plenum|last1=Zhou|first1=Laura|date=24 October 2014|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|access-date=7 September 2019|last2=Huang|first2=Cary|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181030035405/https://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1623286/communist-party-pledges-greater-role-constitution-rights-fourth-plenum|archive-date=30 October 2018|url-status=live}} It also called for more transparency in legal proceedings, more involvement of ordinary citizens in the legislative process, and an overall "professionalization" of the legal workforce. The party also planned to institute cross-jurisdictional circuit legal tribunals as well as giving provinces consolidated administrative oversight over lower level legal resources, which is intended to reduce local government involvement in legal proceedings.{{cite news |last1=Doyon |first1=Jerome |last2=Winckler |first2=Hugo |date=20 November 2014 |title=The Fourth Plenum, Party Officials and Local Courts |work=[[Jamestown Foundation]] |publisher= |url=https://jamestown.org/program/the-fourth-plenum-party-officials-and-local-courts/ |access-date=7 September 2019 |archive-date=18 May 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200518221059/https://jamestown.org/program/the-fourth-plenum-party-officials-and-local-courts/ |url-status=live }} ====Military reforms==== {{see also|Modernization of the People's Liberation Army|2015 People's Republic of China military reform|}}Since taking power in 2012, Xi has undertaken an overhaul of the [[People's Liberation Army]], including both political reform and its modernization.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/china-army-xi/|title=How China is replacing America as Asia's military titan|last1=Lague|first1=David|date=23 April 2019|work=[[Reuters]]|access-date=10 January 2020|last2=Lim|first2=Benjamin Kang|archive-date=21 January 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210121184056/https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/china-army-xi/|url-status=live}} [[Military-civil fusion]] has advanced under Xi.{{Cite journal |last=Bitzinger |first=Richard A. |date=2021 |title=China's Shift from Civil-Military Integration to Military-Civil Fusion |url= |journal=Asia Policy |language=en |volume=28 |issue=1 |pages=5–24 |doi=10.1353/asp.2021.0001 |s2cid=234121234 |issn=1559-2960}}{{cite journal |last1=B. Kania |first1=Elsa |last2=Laskai |first2=Lorand |date=28 January 2021 |title=Myths and Realities of China's Military-Civil Fusion Strategy |url=https://www.cnas.org/publications/reports/myths-and-realities-of-chinas-military-civil-fusion-strategy |website=[[Center for a New American Security]] |jstor=resrep28654 |jstor-access=free |access-date=30 August 2022 |archive-date=16 February 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230216154559/https://www.cnas.org/publications/reports/myths-and-realities-of-chinas-military-civil-fusion-strategy |url-status=live }} Xi has been active in his participation in military affairs, taking a direct hands-on approach to military reform. In addition to being the Chairman of the CMC and leader of the [[Central Leading Group for Military Reform]] founded in 2014 to oversee comprehensive military reforms, Xi has delivered numerous high-profile pronouncements vowing to clean up malfeasance and complacency in the military. Xi has repeatedly warned that the depoliticization of the PLA from the CCP would lead to a collapse similar to that of the Soviet Union.{{Cite news |last=Fifield |first=Anna |author-link=Anna Fifield |date=29 September 2019 |title=China's Communist Party has one more reason to celebrate – a year longer in power than the U.S.S.R. |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/chinas-communist-party-has-one-more-reason-to-celebrate--a-year-longer-in-power-than-the-soviet-union/2019/09/28/993bb832-dfc0-11e9-be7f-4cc85017c36f_story.html |access-date=31 January 2020 |archive-date=1 February 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200201101821/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/chinas-communist-party-has-one-more-reason-to-celebrate--a-year-longer-in-power-than-the-soviet-union/2019/09/28/993bb832-dfc0-11e9-be7f-4cc85017c36f_story.html |url-status=live }} Xi held the New Gutian Conference in 2014, gathering China's top military officers, re-emphasizing the principle of "the party has absolute control over the army" first established by Mao at the 1929 [[Gutian Conference]].{{cite news|url=http://china.dwnews.com/news/2014-11-04/59616798.html|last1=Meng|first1=Chuan|date=4 November 2014|work=[[Duowei News]]|access-date=8 September 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150121184703/http://china.dwnews.com/news/2014-11-04/59616798.html|archive-date=21 January 2015|language=zh-hans|script-title=zh:习近平军中"亮剑" 新古田会议一箭多雕|trans-title=Xi Jinping And Central Army's New "Bright Sword" Conference In Gutian Killed Many Birds With Only A Single Stone}} {{Quote box | quote = In the USSR, where the military was depoliticized, separated from the party and nationalized, the party was disarmed. That makes it riskier than ever |work=[[CNBC]] |publisher= |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/10/31/china-wrote-belt-and-road-initiative-into-the-party-constitution.html |access-date=11 January 2020}} Since the BRI was launched, China became the world's largest lender, lending about $1 trillion in a decade to almost 150 countries. news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/48508182-d426-11e9-8367-807ebd53ab77|archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20221211221202/https://www.ft.com/content/48508182-d426-11e9-8367-807ebd53ab77|archive-date=11 Times]]|access-date=19 January 2020}} Xi made an inspection tour in Xinjiang between 27 and 30 April in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://english.agri.gov.cn/news/dqnf/201405/t20140504_21806.htm|title=President Xi Jinping makes inspection tour in Xinjiang|date=4 May 2014|access-date=7 April 2020|publisher=[[Ministry of birth suppression campaign that led to a large drop in the Uyghur birth rate by 2019.{{cite news |date=28 June 2020 |title=China cuts Uighur births with IUDs, abortion, sterilization |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |url=https://apnews.com/article/269b3de1af34e17c1941a514f78d764c |url-status=live |access-date=18 December 2020
