===COVID-19 pandemic=== {{See also|Chinese government response to COVID-19|COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China}}On 20 January 2020, Xi commented for the first time on the emerging [[COVID-19 pandemic]] in Wuhan, and ordered "efforts to curb the spread" of the virus.{{Cite web |last=Griffiths |first=James |date=17 February 2020 |title=Did Xi Jinping know about the coronavirus outbreak earlier than first suggested? |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/02/17/asia/china-coronavirus-xi-jinping-intl-hnk/index.html |access-date=13 August 2022 |website=[[CNN]]}} He gave premier Li Keqiang some responsibility over the COVID-19 response, in what has been suggested by ''The Wall Street Journal'' was an attempt to potentially insulate himself from criticism if the response failed.{{Cite news |last=Page |first=Jeremy |date=27 January 2020 |title=China's Xi Gives His No. 2 a Rare Chance to Shine in Coronavirus Fight, With Risks for Both |language=en-US |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/chinas-xi-gives-his-no-2-a-rare-chance-to-shine-in-coronavirus-fight-with-risks-for-both-11580138767 |access-date=13 August 2022 |issn=0099-9660}} The government initially responded to the pandemic with a lockdown and censorship, with the initial response causing widespread backlash within China.{{Cite web |last=Griffiths |first=James |title=Wuhan is the latest crisis to face China's Xi, and it's exposing major flaws in his model of control |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/01/23/asia/wuhan-china-coronavirus-sars-response-intl-hnk/index.html |access-date=29 August 2022 |website=[[CNN]]|date=24 January 2020 }} He met with [[Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus]], the director-general of the World Health Organization (WHO), on 28 January.{{Cite web |last=Steger |first=Isabella |date=10 February 2020 |title=Xi Jinping emerges to meet the people for the first time in China's coronavirus outbreak |url=https://qz.com/1799914/xi-jinping-appears-in-public-after-long-absence-during-coronavirus/ |access-date=13 August 2022 |website=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]] |language=en}} ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' reported that in January 2020 Xi pressured Tedros Adhanom to hold off on issuing a [[Public Health Emergency of International Concern|global warning]] about the outbreak of COVID-19 and hold back information on human-to-human transmission of the virus, allegations denied by the WHO.{{cite news |date=10 May 2020 |title=WHO dementiert Telefongespräch mit Chinas Präsident |language=de |website=[[Der Spiegel]] |url=https://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/corona-ausbruch-who-dementiert-telefongespraech-mit-chinas-praesident-a-37678f1c-6960-453c-a317-8ef9feed8b7c}} On 5 February, Xi met with Cambodian prime minister [[Hun Sen]] in Beijing, the first foreign leader allowed into China since the outbreak. After the COVID-19 outbreak got under control in Wuhan, Xi visited the city on 10 March.{{Cite news |last1=Yew |first1=Lun Tian |last2=Se |first2=Young Lee |date=10 March 2022 |title=Xi visits Wuhan, signaling tide turning in China's coronavirus battle |language=en |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-china-idUSKBN20X01F |access-date=13 August 2022}} [[File:Sergio Mattarella and Xi Jinping 2019.jpg|left|thumb|225x225px|Italian president [[Sergio Mattarella]] with Xi in March 2019]] After getting the outbreak in Wuhan under control, Xi has favoured what has officially been termed "dynamic [[Zero-COVID|zero-COVID policy]]"{{Cite web |last=Cao |first=Desheng |title=Xi: Dynamic zero-COVID policy works |url=https://www.chinadaily.com.cn/a/202206/30/WS62bcd80ea310fd2b29e6962b.html |access-date=13 August 2022 |website=[[China Daily]]}} that aims to control and suppress the virus as much as possible within the country's borders. This has involved local lockdowns and mass-testing.{{Cite news |last=Wong |first=Chun Han |date=25 July 2022 |title=China's Zero-Covid Policy Drags on Vaccination Drive |language=en-US |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/chinas-zero-covid-policy-drags-on-vaccination-drive-11658745899 |access-date=13 August 2022 |issn=0099-9660}} While initially credited for China's suppression of the COVID-19 outbreak, the policy was later criticized by foreign and some domestic observers for being out of touch with the rest of the world and taking a heavy toll on the economy. This approach has especially come under criticism during a 2022 lockdown on Shanghai, which forced millions to their homes and damaged the city's economy,{{Cite web |last=Davidson |first=Helen |date=10 June 2022 |title=Xi Jinping says 'persistence is victory' as Covid restrictions return to Shanghai and Beijing |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jun/10/xi-jinping-says-persistence-is-victory-as-covid-restrictions-return-to-shanghai-and-beijing |access-date=29 August 2022 |website=[[The Guardian]] |language=en}} denting the image of [[Li Qiang]], close Xi ally and Party secretary of the city.{{Cite news |last1=Hadano |first1=Tsukasa |last2=Doi |first2=Noriyuki |date=29 June 2022 |title=Xi ally Li Qiang keeps Shanghai party chief job, but star fades |url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/Xi-ally-Li-Qiang-keeps-Shanghai-party-chief-job-but-star-fades |access-date=29 August 2022 |work=[[Nikkei Asia]] |language=en-GB}} Conversely, Xi has said that the policy was designed to protect people's life safety.{{Cite news |last1=Cai |first1=Jane |last2=Tang |first2=Frank |date=29 June 2022 |title=China to press on with 'zero Covid', despite economic risks: Xi |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/china/politics/article/3183550/china-press-zero-covid-despite-economic-risks-president-xi |access-date=13 August 2022 |work=[[South China Morning Post]] |language=en}} On 23 July 2022, the [[National Health Commission]] reported that Xi and other top leaders have taken the local COVID-19 vaccines.{{Cite news |date=23 July 2022 |title=Covid in China: Xi Jinping and other leaders given domestic vaccine |language=en-GB |work=[[BBC News]] |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-62279377 |access-date=13 August 2022}} At the 20th CCP Congress, Xi confirmed the continuation of the zero-COVID policy,{{cite news |last=McDonell |first=Stephen |date=16 October 2022 |title=Xi Jinping speech: Zero-Covid and zero solutions |work=[[BBC News]] |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-63274391 |access-date=11 November 2022}} stating he would "unswervingly" carry out "dynamic zero-COVID" and promising to "resolutely win the battle,"{{Cite news |date=17 December 2022 |title=Xi Jinping tied himself to zero-Covid. Now he keeps silent as it falls apart |work=[[CNN]] |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2022/12/16/china/china-zero-covid-uturn-xi-jinping-intl-hnk-mic/index.html |access-date=16 December 2022}} though China started a limited easing of the policies in the following weeks.{{Cite news |last=Ramzy |first=Austin |date=11 November 2022 |title=China Eases Zero-Covid Rules as Economic Toll and Frustrations Mount |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-eases-some-covid-19-rules-even-as-cases-pass-10-000-11668150369 |access-date=11 November 2022}} In November 2022, [[2022 COVID-19 protests in China|protests]] broke out against China's COVID-19 policies, with a [[2022 Ürümqi fire|fire in a high-rise apartment building in Ürümqi]] being the trigger.{{Cite news |last1=Che |first1=Chang |last2=Buckley |first2=Chris |last3=Chien |first3=Amy Chang |last4=Dong |first4=Joy |date=2022-12-05 |title=China Stems Wave of Protest, but Ripples of Resistance Remain |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/05/world/asia/china-covid-protests.html |access-date=2022-12-05 |issn=0362-4331}} The protests were held in multiple major cities, with some of the protesters demanding the end of Xi's and the CCP's rule. The protests were mostly suppressed by December, though the government further eased COVID-19 restrictions in the time since.{{Cite news |last1=Olcott |first1=Eleanor |last2=Mitchell |first2=Tom |date=4 December 2022 |title=Chinese cities ease Covid restrictions following nationwide protests |work=[[Financial Times]] |url=https://www.ft.com/content/bfbc7afb-3994-4e4c-b649-ca791675b296 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20221211221218/https://www.ft.com/content/bfbc7afb-3994-4e4c-b649-ca791675b296 |archive-date=11 December 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |access-date=5 December 2022 }} On 7 December 2022, China announced large-scale changes to its COVID-19 policy, including allowing quarantine at home for mild infections, reducing of [[Polymerase chain reaction|PCR testing]], and decreasing the power of local officials to implement lockdowns.{{Cite news |last1=Che |first1=Chang |last2=Chien |first2=Amy Chang |last3=Stevenson |first3=Alexandra |date=2022-12-07 |title=What Has Changed About China's 'Zero Covid' Policy |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/07/world/asia/china-zero-covid-changes.html |access-date=2022-12-08 |issn=0362-4331}} ===Environmental policy=== {{Main|Environmental policy in China}}{{See also|Clear waters and green mountains}} In September 2020, Xi announced that China will "strengthen its 2030 climate target (NDC), peak emissions before 2030 and aim to achieve [[carbon neutrality]] before 2060". If accomplished, this would lower the expected rise in global temperature by 0.2–0.3 °C – "the biggest single reduction ever estimated by the Climate Action Tracker".{{cite web |date=23 September 2020 |title=China going carbon neutral before 2060 would lower warming projections by around 0.2 to 0.3 degrees C |url=https://climateactiontracker.org/press/china-carbon-neutral-before-2060-would-lower-warming-projections-by-around-2-to-3-tenths-of-a-degree/ |access-date=27 September 2020 |website=[[Climate Action Tracker]]}} Xi mentioned the link between the COVID-19 pandemic and nature destruction as one of the reasons for the decision, saying that "Humankind can no longer afford to ignore the repeated warnings of nature."{{cite news |date=23 September 2020 |title=China, the world's top global emitter, aims to go carbon-neutral by 2060 |work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |publisher= |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-09-23/china-world-top-global-emitter-aims-carbon-neutral-by-2060/12691974 |access-date=29 September 2020}} On 27 September, Chinese scientists presented a detailed plan how to achieve the target.{{cite news |date=29 September 2020 |title=China's top climate scientists unveil road map to 2060 goal |newspaper=[[The Japan Times]] |agency=[[Bloomberg News]] |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/09/29/asia-pacific/science-health-asia-pacific/china-climate-change-road-map-2060/ |access-date=29 September 2020}} In September 2021, Xi announced that China will not build "coal-fired power projects abroad, which was said to be potentially "pivotal" in reducing emissions. The Belt and Road Initiative did not include financing such projects already in the first half of 2021.{{cite news |last1=Brant |first1=Robin |date=22 September 2021 |title=China pledges to stop building new coal energy plants abroad |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher= |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-58647481 |access-date=29 September 2021}} Xi Jinping did not attend [[2021 United Nations Climate Change Conference|COP26]] personally. However, a Chinese delegation led by climate change envoy [[Xie Zhenhua (politician)|Xie Zhenhua]] did attend.{{Cite news |last=Faulconbridge |first=Guy |date=15 October 2021 |title=China's Xi will not attend COP26 in person, UK PM Johnson told |work=[[Reuters]] |publisher= |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/chinas-xi-snub-cop26-uk-pm-johnson-told-times-2021-10-15/ |access-date=20 August 2022}}{{Cite news |last=Harvey |first=Fiona |date=10 November 2021 |title=China's top Cop26 delegate says it is taking 'real action' on climate targets |work=[[The Guardian]] |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2021/nov/10/chinas-top-cop26-delegate-says-it-is-taking-real-action-on-climate-targets |access-date=11 November 2022}} During the conference, the United States and China agreed on a framework to reduce [[GHG emission]] by co-operating on different measures.{{cite news |last1=Volcovici |first1=Valeria |last2=James |first2=William |last3=Spring |first3=Jake |date=11 November 2021 |title=U.S. and China unveil deal to ramp up cooperation on climate change |work=[[Reuters]] |publisher= |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/cop/china-us-make-joint-statement-cop26-climate-summit-2021-11-10 |access-date=11 November 2021}} ===Governance style=== Known as a very secretive leader, little is known publicly about how Xi makes political decisions, or how he came to power.{{Cite news |date=28 September 2022 |title=An investigation into what has shaped Xi Jinping's thinking |newspaper=[[The Economist]] |url=https://www.economist.com/briefing/2022/09/28/an-investigation-into-what-has-shaped-xi-jinpings-thinking |access-date=30 September 2022 |issn=0013-0613}}{{Cite news |last=Myers |first=Steven Lee |date=5 March 2018 |title=Behind Public Persona, the Real Xi Jinping Is a Guarded Secret |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/05/world/asia/xi-jinping-china-leader.html |access-date=13 August 2022 |issn=0362-4331}} Xi's speeches generally get released months or years after they are made. Xi has also never given a press conference since becoming paramount leader, except in rare joint press conferences with foreign leaders.{{Cite web |last=McGregor |first=Richard |date=21 August 2022 |title=Xi Jinping's Radical Secrecy |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2022/08/china-xi-jinping-biography-opacity/671195/ |access-date=21 August 2022 |website=[[The Atlantic]] |language=en}} ''The Wall Street Journal'' reported that Xi prefers micromanaging in governance, in contrast to previous leaders such as Hu Jintao who left details of major policies to lower-ranking officials. Reportedly, ministerial officials try to get Xi's attention in various ways, with some creating slide shows and audio reports. ''The Wall Street Journal'' also reported that Xi created a performance-review system in 2018 to give evaluations on officials on various measures, including loyalty. According to ''The Economist'', Xi's orders have generally been vague, leaving lower level officials to interpret his words.{{Cite news |title=Even in secret, China's leaders speak in code |newspaper=[[The Economist]] |url=https://www.economist.com/china/2022/01/01/even-in-secret-chinas-leaders-speak-in-code |access-date=13 August 2022 |issn=0013-0613}} Chinese state media Xinhua News Agency said that Xi "personally reviews every draft of major policy documents" and "all reports submitted to him, no matter how late in the evening, were returned with instructions the following {{further|Ideology of the Chinese Communist Party}} ===Chinese Dream=== {{main|Chinese Dream}} [[File:Lujiazui 2016.jpg|thumb|According to ''[[Qiushi]]'', the Chinese Dream is about Chinese prosperity, collective effort, socialism, and national glory.]] Xi and CCP ideologues coined the phrase "Chinese Dream" to describe his overarching plans for China as its leader. Xi first used the phrase during a high-profile visit to the [[National Museum of China]] on 29 November 2012, where he and his [[Politburo Standing Committee of the Chinese Communist Party|Standing Committee]] colleagues were attending a "national revival" exhibition. Since then, the phrase has become the signature political slogan of the Xi era.{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/leaders/2013/05/04/xi-jinping-and-the-chinese-dream|title=Xi Jinping and the Chinese dream|date=4 May 2013|newspaper=[[The Economist]]|access-date=12 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160510092423/http://www.economist.com/news/leaders/21577070-vision-chinas-new-president-should-serve-his-people-not-nationalist-state-xi-jinping|archive-date=10 May 2016|issn=0013-0613}}{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/9935609/Xi-Jinping-calls-for-a-Chinese-Dream.html|title=Xi Jinping calls for a Chinese dream|last1=Moore|first1=Malcolm|date=17 March 2013|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|access-date=20 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130320072154/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/9935609/Xi-Jinping-calls-for-a-Chinese-Dream.html|archive-date=20 March 2013|url-status=live}} The origin of the term "Chinese Dream" is unclear. While the phrase has been used before by journalists and scholars,{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/china/archive/2013/05/todays-china-notes-dreams-obstacles/275544/|title=Today's China Notes: Dreams, Obstacles|last=Fallows|first=James|date=3 May 2013|work=[[The Atlantic]]|access-date=7 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180712023142/https://www.theatlantic.com/china/archive/2013/05/todays-china-notes-dreams-obstacles/275544/|archive-date=12 July 2018|url-status=live}} some publications have posited the term likely drew its inspiration from the concept of the [[American Dream]].{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/analects/2013/05/chinese-dream-0|title=The role of Thomas Friedman|last=M.|first=J.|date=6 May 2013|newspaper=[[The Economist]]|access-date=12 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028145059/https://www.economist.com/blogs/analects/2013/05/chinese-dream-0|archive-date=28 October 2017|url-status=live}} ''The Economist'' noted the abstract and seemingly accessible nature of the concept with no specific overarching policy stipulations may be a deliberate departure from the jargon-heavy ideologies of his predecessors.{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21577063-chinas-new-leader-has-been-quick-consolidate-his-power-what-does-he-now-want-his|title=Chasing the Chinese dream |date=4 May 2013|newspaper=[[The Economist]]|access-date=12 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028080732/http://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21577063-chinas-new-leader-has-been-quick-consolidate-his-power-what-does-he-now-want-his|archive-date=28 October 2016|issn=0013-0613}} Xi has linked the "Chinese Dream" with the phrase "great rejuvenation of the Chinese nation".{{Cite web |last=Tao |first=Xie |date=14 March 2014 |title=Opinion: Is the Chinese dream fantasy or reality? |url=https://www.cnn.com/2014/03/14/world/asia/chinese-dream-anniversary-xi-jinping-president/index.html |access-date=14 August 2022 |website=[[CNN]]}}{{efn|{{zh|links=no|s=中华民族伟大复兴}}, which can also be translated as the "Great Renaissance of the Chinese nation" or the "Great revival of the Chinese people".}} ===Cultural revival=== In recent years, top political leaders of the CCP such as Xi have overseen the rehabilitation of ancient Chinese philosophical figures like [[Han Fei]] into the mainstream of Chinese thought alongside [[Confucianism]]. At a meeting with other officials in 2013, he quoted [[Confucius]], saying "he who rules by virtue is like the Pole Star, it maintains its place, and the multitude of stars pay homage." While visiting [[Shandong]], the birthplace of Confucius, in November, he told scholars that the Western world was "suffering a crisis of confidence" and that the CCP has been "the loyal inheritor and promoter of China's outstanding [[Traditional Chinese culture|traditional culture]]."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/12/world/leader-taps-into-chinese-classics-in-seeking-to-cement-power.html|title=Leader Taps into Chinese Classics in Seeking to Cement Power|last=Buckley|first=Chris|date=12 October 2014|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190912091736/https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/12/world/leader-taps-into-chinese-classics-in-seeking-to-cement-power.html|archive-date=12 September 2019|access-date=7 September 2019}} According to several analysts, Xi's leadership has been characterised by a resurgence of the ancient political philosophy [[Legalism (Chinese philosophy)|Legalism]].{{cite journal |last1=Schneider |first1=David K. |title=China's New Legalism |journal=The National Interest |date=2016 |issue=143 |pages=19–25 |doi= |jstor=26557304 }}{{cite web |last1=Crane |first1=Sam |title=Why Xi Jinping's China is Legalist, Not Confucian |url=https://chinachannel.org/2018/06/29/legalism/ |website=China Channel |date=29 June 2018 |access-date=24 November 2020 |archive-date=7 November 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201107225951/https://chinachannel.org/2018/06/29/legalism/ |url-status=dead }} Han Fei gained new prominence with favourable citations; one sentence of Han Fei's that Xi quoted appeared thousands of times in official Chinese media at the local, provincial, and national levels.{{cite news|url=https://thediplomat.com/2015/01/is-chinas-machiavelli-now-its-most-important-political-philosopher/|title=Is 'China's Machiavelli' Now Its Most Important Political Philosopher?|last=Mitchell|first=Ryan Mi|date=16 January 2015|newspaper=[[The Diplomat]]|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190912091739/https://thediplomat.com/2015/01/is-chinas-machiavelli-now-its-most-important-political-philosopher/|archive-date=12 September 2019|access-date=7 September 2019}} Xi has additionally supported the [[Neo-Confucianism|Neo-Confucian]] philosopher [[Wang Yangming]], telling local leaders to promote him.{{Cite news |last=Johnson |first=Ian |date=18 October 2017 |title=Forget Marx and Mao. Chinese City Honors Once-Banned Confucian. |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/18/world/asia/china-guiyang-wang-yangming-confucian.html |access-date=13 August 2022 |issn=0362-4331}} Xi has also overseen a revival of traditional Chinese culture, breaking from the CCP's previous path, which had often attacked it.{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/china/2017/08/17/the-communist-party-is-redefining-what-it-means-to-be-chinese|title=The Communist Party is redefining what it means to be Chinese|date=17 August 2017|newspaper=[[The Economist]]|access-date=23 January 2020}} He has called traditional culture the "soul" of the nation and the "foundation" of the CCP's culture.{{Cite news |last=Zi |first=Yang |date=6 July 2016 |title=Xi Jinping and China's Traditionalist Restoration |work=[[The Jamestown Foundation]] |publisher= |url=https://jamestown.org/program/xi-jinping-chinas-traditionalist-restoration/ |access-date=23 January 2020}} Xi has also called for integrating the basic tenets of Marxism with China's traditional culture. [[Hanfu]], the traditional dress of Han Chinese, has seen a revival under him, associated with the revival of traditional culture.{{Cite news|url=https://www.afr.com/life-and-luxury/fashion-and-style/why-its-hip-to-be-oldfashioned-in-china-20181129-h18hql|title=China's 'Hanfu' movement is making it hip to be old-fashioned. Here's why.|last=Buckley|first=Chris|date=30 November 2018|work=[[The Australian Financial Review]]|access-date=23 January 2020}} He has established the "[[Confidence doctrine|four matters of confidence]]", which has later been added to the CCP constitution, calling for CCP members, government officials and the Chinese people to be "confident in our chosen path, confident in our guiding theories, confident in our political system, and confident in our culture". He has unveiled Global Civilisation initiative in 2023, calling for "respecting the diversity of civilisations, advocating the common values of humanity, valuing the inheritance and innovation of civilisations, and strengthening international people-to-people exchanges and cooperation" ===Ideology=== {{See also|Eight-point Regulation}} Xi has said that "only socialism can save China".{{Cite news |last=Tian |first=Yew Lun |date=9 September 2021 |title=Analysis: Unleashing reforms, Xi returns to China's socialist roots |language=en |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/china/unleashing-reforms-xi-returns-chinas-socialist-roots-2021-09-09/ |access-date=17 September 2022}} Xi has also declared [[socialism with Chinese rejuvenation: Xi |url=http://ex.chinadaily.com.cn/exchange/partners/82/rss/channel/www/columns/np4922/stories/WS61610570a310cdd39bc6dcc1.html |access-date=17 September 2022 |website=[[China Daily]]}} According to [[BBC News]], while the CCP was perceived to have abandoned its communist ideology since it initiated [[Chinese economic reform|economic reforms]] in the 1970s, Xi is believed by some observers to be more believing in the "idea of a communist project",{{Cite news |last=McDonell |first=Stephen |date=22 September 2021 |title=Changing China: Xi Jinping's effort to return to socialism |language=en-GB |work=[[BBC News]] |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-58579831 |access-date=17 September 2022}} being described as a [[Marxist–Leninist]] by former Australian prime minister Kevin Rudd.{{Cite news |last=Rudd |first=Kevin |author-link=Kevin Rudd |date=10 October 2022 |title=The World According to Xi Jinping |language=en-US |work=[[Foreign Affairs]] |url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/china/world-according-xi-jinping-china-ideologue-kevin-rudd |access-date=12 October 2022}} Xi's emphasis on prioritizing ideology has included re-asserting the Party's goal of eventually [[Communist mode of production|realizing communism]] and reprimanding those who dismiss communism as impractical or irrelevant.{{sfn|Pieke|Hofman|2022|p=48}} Xi described the communist ideal as the "calcium" in a Party member's spine, without which the Party member would suffer the "osteoporosis" of political decay and be unable to stand upright.{{sfn|Pieke|Hofman|2022|p=48}} Subscribing to the view that socialism will eventually triumph over capitalism, Xi has said "Marx and Engels's [[Dialectical materialism|analysis of the basic contradictions]] of [[Capitalist mode of production (Marxist theory)|capitalist society]] is not outdated, nor is the [[historical materialism|historical materialist view]] that capitalism is bound to die out and socialism bound to win".{{Cite web |last=Hancock |first=Tom |date=6 June 2022 |title=Marxism Makes a Comeback in China's Crackdown on 'Disorderly Capital' the increase of "Socialist Political Economy With Chinese Characteristics" as a major study topic for academics in China, aiming to decrease the influence of Western-influenced economics. Though he has called a stop to what he considers to be "disorderly expansion of capital", he has also said that "it is necessary to stimulate the vitality of capital of all types, including nonpublic capital, and give full play to its positive role". {{Quote box | quote = China's success proves that socialism is not dead. despite many setbacks, has achieved great progress under the CCP, saying that "socialism with Chinese characteristics has become the standard-bearer of 21st-century socialist development".{{Cite web |last=Zheng |first=William |date=16 September 2022 |title=Xi article gives insight into China's direction ahead of party congress |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/china/politics/article/3192677/xi-article-gives-insight-chinas-direction-ahead-party-congress |access-date=17 September 2022 |website=[[South China Morning Post]] |language=en}} However, he has also warned that it will take a long time for China under the CCP to complete its rejuvenation, and during this timeframe, party members must be vigilant to not let CCP rule collapse. Xi has ruled out a [[multi-party system]] for China, saying that "constitutional monarchy, imperial restoration, parliamentarism, a multi-party system and a presidential system, we considered them, tried them, but none worked".{{Cite news |date=2 April 2014 |title=Xi says multi-party system didn't work for China |language=en |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-politics-xi-idUSBREA3107S20140402 |access-date=13 August 2022}} However, Xi considers China to be a [[Democracy in China|democracy]], saying that "China's [[socialist democracy]] is the most comprehensive, genuine and effective democracy".{{Cite web |title=Democracy |url=https://decodingchina.eu/democracy/ |access-date=13 August 2022 |website=Decoding China |date=4 February 2021 |language=en-US}} China's definition of democracy is different from [[liberal democracies]] and is rooted in Marxism–Leninism, and is based on the phrases "[[people's democratic dictatorship]]" and "[[democratic centralism]]". Xi has additionally coined the term "whole-process people's democracy" which he said was about having "the people as masters".{{Cite web |last=Chen |first=Stella |date=23 November 2021 |title=Whole-Process Democracy |url=https://chinamediaproject.org/the_ccp_dictionary/whole-process-democracy/ |access-date=13 August 2022 |website=China Media Project |language=en-US}} Foreign made mention of the "Thought on Socialism with Chinese Characteristics for a New Era" in his opening day speech delivered to the 19th Party Congress in October 2017. His Politburo Standing Committee colleagues, in their own reviews of Xi's keynote address at the Congress, prepended the name "Xi Jinping" in front of "Thought".{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-10/19/c_136689808.htm|title=CPC creates Xi Jinping Thought on Socialism with Chinese Characteristics for a New Era|last1=Zhang|first1=Ling|date=18 October 2017|work=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|access-date=19 October 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171018195301/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-10/19/c_136689808.htm|archive-date=18 October 2017|url-status=dead}} On 24 October 2017, at its closing session, the 19th Party Congress approved the incorporation of Xi Jinping Thought into the Constitution of the CCP, while in March 2018, the National People's Congress changed the state constitution to include Xi Jinping Thought.{{Cite web |last=Ken |first=Suzuki |date=27 November 2018 |title=China's New "Xi Jinping Constitution": The Road to Totalitarianism |url=https://www.nippon.com/en/in-depth/a05803/ |access-date=11 August 2022 |website=nippon.com |language=en}} [[File:201901 Xi Jinping's books at Shanghai Library.jpg|left|thumb|''[[The Governance of China]]'' in different languages presented at [[Shanghai Library]]]] Xi himself has described the Thought as part of the broad framework created around [[socialism with Chinese characteristics]], a term coined by Deng Xiaoping that places China in the [[primary stage of socialism]]. In official party documentation and pronouncements by Xi's colleagues, the Thought is said to be a continuation of [[Marxism–Leninism]], [[Mao Zedong Thought]], Deng Xiaoping Theory, the Three Represents, and the [[Scientific Outlook on Development]], as part of a series of guiding ideologies that embody "Marxism adopted to Chinese conditions" and contemporary considerations. It has additionally been described as the "21st century Marxism" by two professors in the Central Party School of the CCP. Wang Huning, a top political adviser and a close ally of Xi, has been described as pivotal to developing Xi Jinping Thought. The concepts and context behind Xi Jinping Thought are elaborated in Xi's ''[[The Governance of China]]'' book series, published by the [[Foreign Languages Press]] for an international audience. Volume one was published in September 2014, followed by volume two in November 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-11/07/c_136733705.htm|title=Second volume of Xi's book on governance published|last=Yang|first=Yi|date=7 November 2017|publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171206143920/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-11/07/c_136733705.htm|archive-date=6 December 2017|access-date=6 December 2017}} An app for teaching Xi Jinping Thought had become the most popular smartphone app in China in 2019, as the country's ruling CCP launched a new campaign that calls on its cadres to immerse themselves in the political doctrine every day. ''[[Xuexi Qiangguo]]'' is now the most downloaded item on Apple's domestic App Store, surpassing in demand social media apps such as WeChat and TikTok.{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/tech/apps-social/article/2186037/chinas-most-popular-app-propaganda-tool-teaching-xi-jinping-thought|title=China's most popular app is a propaganda tool teaching Xi Jinping Thought|last=Huang|first=Zheping|date=14 February 2019|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|access-date=7 September 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190920105809/https://www.scmp.com/tech/apps-social/article/2186037/chinas-most-popular-app-propaganda-tool-teaching-xi-jinping-thought|archive-date=20 September 2019}} In 2021, the government included Xi Jinping Thought in the curriculum including to students from primary schools to university, which created pushback from parents. For much of the preceding 30 years, political ideology and communist doctrine were not a standard taught in Chinese schools until middle school, and textbooks featured a wider set of Chinese leaders with less emphasis on a single leader like Xi.{{cite news |last=Sun |first=Yu |date=29 August 2021 |title=Lessons on Xi Jinping's political philosophy alarm Chinese parents |work=[[Irish Times]] |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/asia-pacific/lessons-on-xi-jinping-s-political-philosophy-alarm-chinese-parents-1.4659194 |access-date=7 September 2021 |quote=A campaign to make Chinese children as young as 10 study President Xi Jinping's political philosophy has been labelled by some parents as 'disgusting', and evoked memories of Mao Zedong's personality cult.}} ==Personal life== ===Family=== [[File:Peng Liyuan, Xi Jinping and Barack Obama in the Lincoln Bedroom.jpg|thumb|Xi Jinping, [[Peng Liyuan]] and U.S. president [[Barack Obama]] in the Lincoln Bedroom]] Xi's first marriage was to [[Ke Lingling]], the daughter of [[Ke Hua]], China's ambassador to the United Kingdom in the early 1980s. They divorced within a few years.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/11/07/world/asia/china-xi-jinping-profile/index.html|title=Xi Jinping: From 'sent-down youth' to China's top|last=Yuan|first=Elizabeth|date=8 November 2012|publisher=[[CNN]]|access-date=8 November 2012|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108195546/http://edition.cnn.com/2012/11/07/world/asia/china-xi-jinping-profile/index.html|archive-date=8 November 2012}} The two were said to fight "almost every day", and after the divorce Ke moved to England. In 1987, Xi married the prominent Chinese folk singer Peng Liyuan.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/oct/23/world/fg-chileaders23|title=China's 'fifth generation' of leaders reflects nation's shifts|last=Magnier|first=Mark|date=23 October 2007|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|access-date=21 December 2009|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110823133224/http://articles.latimes.com/2007/oct/23/world/fg-chileaders23|archive-date=23 August 2011}} Xi and Peng were introduced by friends as many Chinese couples were in the 1980s. Xi was reputedly academic during their courtship, inquiring about singing techniques.{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2012/02/13/peng-liyuan-meet-chinas-folk-song-singing-first-lady-in-waiting/|title=Meet China's Folk Star First Lady-in-Waiting|last=Page|first=Jeremy|date=12 February 2012|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|access-date=7 November 2012|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511045002/http://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2012/02/13/peng-liyuan-meet-chinas-folk-song-singing-first-lady-in-waiting/|archive-date=11 May 2012}} Peng Liyuan, a [[Celebrity|household name]] in China, was better known to the public than Xi until his political elevation. The couple frequently lived apart due largely to their separate professional lives. Peng has played a much more visible role as China's "first lady" compared to her predecessors; for example, Peng hosted U.S. First Lady [[Michelle Obama]] on her high-profile visit to China in March 2014.{{cite news|url=http://time.com/33164/michelle-obama-china-beijing-peng-liyuan/|title=Michelle Obama Tours Beijing With China's First Lady|last1=Beech|first1=Hannah|date=21 March 2014|newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|access-date=17 July 2014|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140626122108/http://time.com/33164/michelle-obama-china-beijing-peng-liyuan/|archive-date=26 June 2014}} Xi and Peng have a daughter named [[Xi Mingze]], who graduated from [[Harvard University]] in the spring of 2015. He was described as a good hand at problem solving and "seemingly uninterested in the trappings of high office".{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia-pacific/xi-jinping-likely-chinas-next-leader-called-pragmatic-low-key/2011/08/15/gIQA5W83GJ_story.html|title=Xi Jinping, likely China's next leader, called pragmatic, low-key|last=Richburg|first=Keith B.|date=15 August 2011|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=7 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191029173940/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia-pacific/xi-jinping-likely-chinas-next-leader-called-pragmatic-low-key/2011/08/15/gIQA5W83GJ_story.html|archive-date=29 October 2019|url-status=live}} ===Soccer=== Xi is an avid soccer fan.{{cite web|url=https://www.chinadaily.com.cn/a/202310/10/WS65250929a31090682a5e7bf1.html|title=Xi shows off his football skill|work=[[China Daily]]|date=2023-10-10}} According to reports, when working in Hebei, Xi often asked his friend [[Nie Weiping]], a professional [[Go (game)|Go]] player, for soccer tickets. The two walked out of a match between [[China national football team|Chinese national team]] and a team from UK because they disappointed at the performance of the Chinese team.{{cite web|url=https://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2014-10/11/content_18723212_6.htm|title=What saddens President Xi Jinping?|work=[[China Daily]]|date=2014-10-11}} During a visit to [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] in 2012 as China's vice-president, Xi showcased his soccer technique at the [[Croke Park]]. In 2011, Xi outlined a vision to turn China from a footballing [[minnow]] to a soccer superpower. He outlined a three stage plan for the national team: to qualify for another [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]], to host a World Cup and to win a World Cup.{{cite web|author1=Andrew McNicol|author2=Andrew Raine|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2023/04/07/china/xi-jinping-china-football-dream-fail-intl-hnk-dst/index.html|title=Xi Jinping wanted China to be a global soccer power. What went wrong?|work=[[CNN]]|date=2023-04-07}} In 2015, Xi approved China’s 50-point plan for the sport, which included including soccer in the national school curriculum and setting up 50,000 soccer schools in the country by 2025.{{cite web|author=Tariq Panja|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/29/sports/soccer/china-soccer.html|title=China’s Soccer Experiment Was a Flop. Now It May Be Over.|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2023-03-29}} However, according to [[CNN]], poor financial decisions and alleged high-level corruption coupled with a [[COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China|three-year pandemic]] have left the sport in tatters. In 2023, Xi said he is "not so sure" of the abilities of the national team.{{cite web|date=2023-11-19|work=[[CNA (TV network)|Channel NewsAsia]]|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/asia/china-xi-not-so-sure-football-team-abilities-world-cup-3931906|title=Xi says 'not so sure' of Chinese football team's abilities}} ==Public life== It is hard to gauge the opinion of the Chinese public on Xi, as no independent surveys exist in China and social media is heavily censored.{{Cite news |last=Lin |first=Liza |date=13 October 2022 |title=Do Chinese People Like Xi Jinping?
